This is horrific. There will never be closure--even though I despise that word...

My husband went missing on Aug 1...just gone. His body was finally found four months later on the slopes of Diamond Head...3 blocks from our home. No cause of death was ever found...despite shows such as CSI, Cold Case, or Bones, the ME said that many times no cause can be found. "Body was too decomposed." Hardly the way I wanted to remember my best friend in the world..

I have tried to go through every scenario in my mind...what went wrong? He was finishing his dissertation. He had a tenured position at a private university in post grad IT.

For four months I called every emergency room starting at 4 am. I went to every homeless shelter on the island (There are 950,000 residents in the City and County of Honolulu...much less the 300,000 tourists in Waikiki.) I combed the harbors, derelict boats...he couldn't leave the island without ID. Was he hurt? Was he in pain?

His wallet, credit cards, money, keys, cell phone all on his desk...Front door left open..our dog was loose outside.

And for one week before his "disappearance" he had insomnia or was sleeping all the time..

I so empathize with the family and friends...I had to leave Hawai'i forever...I was so haunted by all of this...

I so hope his family and friends find comfort in each other's love...just remember how wonderful he was...try to forget the last two weeks of his life.......

I found out when my husband's body was found after being missing for 4 months that many times, no cause of death can be determined...unlike the crazy stories on CSI, Cold Case, and Bones.

The Medical Examiner and Missing Persons deal with this all the time....there is absolutely NO reason to keep something from the family.

We watch TV and movies and think they reflect real life..they don't. Not at all.

Wow! Really? You are an expert on CTE? (Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy)?

Rather than trying to make a case for this...be careful. CTE doesn't usually present so quickly. He was a quarterback not a lineman or linebacker who sustains terrible hits on nearly EVERY play. (Such as Junior Seau).

He could have had a seizure which may have had NOTHING to do with any football injury. As a neurologist, we usually associate seizures in anyone ever 35 as a scar, acute bleeding, or tumor...But UNDER 35 we usually never find any etiology..ever.

He could have had a heart arrhythmia or abnormal electrolytes, dozens of things! It is foolish to make such broad statements as your last sentence..

Who concluded that head injury was the cause of this tragedy?

If the author's goal was to write a feature article about a talented and successful football player; a gentle-giant with a supersized, gregarious personality with a positive impact on those closest and farthest from him, then it was a successful endeavor.  Cullen Finnerty’s death is sad and tragic and a tremendous loss for his family.

However, if the author intended to portray his death as another example of the perils of football and of repetitive head injury, then it was misguided and falls short.  Cullen Finnerty played football, apparently with an aggressive style more suited to a linebacker.  Yet,
isn’t that how the linebacker plays all the time?  Aren’t there several other players who have suffered more head trauma without developing vague paranoia and personality changes?  While it seems obvious that repetitive head trauma isn’t healthy, it isn’t yet clear
what changes occur as a result of head trauma and how those changes affect cognition, behavior and physical and mental health.  It isn’t clear if certain people have an increased susceptibility to head
trauma while others heal without sequelae.  There are many unanswered questions and inadequate evidence.

Cullen Finnerty’s death is a tragedy in more ways than can be counted.  I am sorry for his family’s loss.  However, concluding that head injury was the cause of this tragedy is premature and reckless.  It is easy to blame football, but conjecture should be set aside until there is evidence supporting it.

It's possible that brain trauma had something to do with his death, but one should wait for the test results.

Not that this was your point as you say nothing really relevant to this article (and your last sentence is particularly gratuitous).

They really need to change the name of football to brain trauma ball.

The harsh violence, head-banging, whiplash and concussive force that accompanies every football make it a delayed time bomb for traumatic brain injury.

Some players will be unaffected, but many will suffer horrific brain deformities because of the violence of football.

Football is like religion to many people, and neither has proven to enhance brain function.

Despite your castigating the US, yours is actually a very US-centric narcissistic view and an over-simplistic narrative. The tension between US and China isn't about the US desire for hegemony. There are many actors in this drama, and they are not simply US puppets.

For example, the US is not "militarizing" Japan. The JSDF has been fairly well-armed historically, and Japan to move toward a more assertive international position is driven by the Japanese government which has recently taken a more nationalistic turn when Shinzo Abe returned to power. China has been worsening the situation because of its hard line with regard to the dispute Diaoyutai.

Japan is not the only neighbor of China who is getting nervous. China is casting a long shadow in the region.

China has been undergoing major military build up and modernization long before the recent American strategic re-alignment. As the phrase goes, "it takes two to tango." The US and China rank numbers 1 and 2 in military expenditure. China aims its missiles at the US and US-allies just as the US aims its missiles at China.

It's not a story of peace-loving China versus warmongering US. It's a story of competing geopolitical interests with two willing players.
Thank you, Mr. Pollack, for an intelligent and informed comment amid so much verbal gas and fog.

We seem to have left something out: the "pivot," or Pacific-first strategy, which represents the geostrategic framework of moving military resources to that region in order to contain, and ultimately isolate, China. The US has been confrontational, with Obama seeking to reclaim America's unilateral course of global hegemony--a course no longer viable given China's increasing economic strength (along with a multipolar world power structure, as in Third World emerging industrialization).

China has not made similar military movements against America. Mr. Xi is not stupid. Sunnylands is a pro forma diplomatic exercise and, so long as the US seeks to rekindle the Cold War via its presence in South Asia, efforts to militarize Japan, and the shoring up of military alliances in the region, it will come to nothing. How can China trust Obama, when he and his national-security advisers have placed China on the enemies-list (alongside that of suspected terrorists)? China's "crime" appears to be that it has run circles around US capitalism, gaining markets in Africa and Latin America (and now, a significant portion of the Iraqi OIL supply), through, not intervention, but building soccer fields and health clinics, and, in Iraq, settling for lower profit margins.

We could learn a lot about international economics from China, if we weren't so arrogant and heavy-handed.

It must be very frustrating to spread out a delectable item (free! cool! high performance!) and have people reject it and apparently just not "get it". I can imagine that would be very irritating.

But many of your readers aren't techies. It's easy to make fun of some of the responses that showed readers who didn't understand what you wrote, or who are a little naïve. But digital security is a serious issue indeed, and I think your readers are to be applauded, for wanting to take a measured and thoughtful approach to this issue.

I'm an I/T professional, and am generally an early and enthusiastic adopter of new technology, from the first Palm Pilots,to on-line banking and stock trading,to the iPad and iPhone. I'm currently going paperless in my office using a Fujitsu ScanSnap, and I've used Carbonite for off-site backup for years, and highly recommend their service. I do "get it". But I also have reservations about the password vault concept, especially when a user's full name, address, and other information useful for identity theft are in the vault. Yes, there's no risk if everything works as designed . . . but in my experience that doesn't always happen. Obviously, you feel strongly otherwise, and that's fine. My real point is just that serious, thoughtful people can see this issue differently . . . and accusing your readers of being paranoid Luddites if they disagree with you . . . doesn't do much to expand the communications channel.

"All we have to fear is fear itself." -FDR

This is a misleadingly simple statement. It has many layers, and much unfolds from it when not heeded

In the face of much more real terror, Winston Churchill, in his finest hour speech especially, did not summon his country's fears, but instead their courage

It's worth taking a moment to review some of the contents of his "Finest Hour" speech. He lays out the situation clearly: left no dark corners. Moreover, he concludes the speech with this assesment: that if Hitler succeeds, a new dark age would emerge in Western Civilization, but if England succeeds, then a new golden age would emerge. With those stakes, he was able to summon his nation's courage, their "finest hour" - thus labeling an age. I get goose bumps every time I read it, because we all know that a new very dark age had already settled over Europe yet we know that the English did summon their courage, that they did succeed, that as a result a new golden age, in fact history's golden-est of golden ages, the post war boom which doubled global economic output in less than 30 years did indeed occur. And England was at the very center of that Golden Age, especially for fashion and music in the 1960s

FDR did the same.His mixed economy was the basis of that Golden Age that saw us land on the moon

What we have is a generational failure of our Elites.They've been failing us at every turn. It seems they are the ones who are afraid and act accordingly. We need to transcend them

College Football and Basketball have been nothing but farm teams for the NFL and NBA. Okay the NBA may have a D section (Instructional league)...but not much else. So these two leagues don't have to pay a penny for farm teams that are the building blocks that take kids to the show, MLB. MLB has to run Rookie to Triple A clubs...brIng kids up though a farm system WHERE THEY ARE PAID!

It is naive and disingenuous to keep calling these college players "student-athletes." It is time to start paying these guys. Nick Saban of the Alabama Crimson Tide wants to pay players "$4,000" for season...while Saban makes $5 MILLION a year. Ridiculous! Nick Saban isn't a defensive end rushing an opposing QB--his unpaid team is doing that!

It 's time to look at college sports as farm teams for the pros. No two ways about it! . Tuition, books, housing and food just doesn't cover it. In basketball a high school player can go to the NBA immediately or do a "One and done." Not so in football...they cannot come out until they have played at least two years of college ball...or their college class has.

This whole transfer mess reminds me of MLB before Curt Flood decided that he wasn't "owned" anymore by the coach and executives....and then we entered free agency. It's time we made at least the SEC a farm league for the NFL. Good heavens the most players to play in the NFL are always from the SEC! Let's bring it ALL out in the open. Big Ten, ACC, Big Twelve, Pac-12, Big East etc.

They need that money when they are playing! And what happens if the player is injured...does he still get money from a deferred trust? What if he transfers? What if he plays at an IVY league school where they have no scholarships?

No these kids need to be paid for playing...Period. To see the top two biggest stadiums Alabama and Big Blue in Michigan filled to 100 plus thousand every game with very rich alumni---a few seats for students...and the kids on the field aren't getting paid?? Completely wrong.
